Altanchimeg began selling foodstuffs in 2008. She rents a stall at a local market and her current working capital exceeds 1,000,000 MNT. She wants to expand her business and increase her profits. Altanchimeg is a hardworking and modest person who says, " I work hard to expand my business and save money for my children's future study". She is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 MNT to purchase more food items for her business.

loans.use: to purchase more foodstuffs

loans.name: Sophay

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophay H. (pictured above), 40, is a weaver. She has three daughters, two are in school and another is still young. Her husband, Mr. Sal Sen, is a construction worker. The family lives across the Mekong River and about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Sophay hopes to continue her weaving business, so she is asking for a loan of US$100 to purchase weaving materials.

loans.use: to purchase weaving materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Chuon

texts.en: Chuon O. has been operating her own small business in the local market for years in Kompong Chhnang province. She sells various kinds of vegetables and makes a profit about $7.5 each day to help support in the whole family. She doesn’t have a life partner because her husband died of an illness several years ago. Presently, she has two children with her; one of them also sells vegetables in the market, and the other one is an unemployed man. In order to earn extra income and to make her business successful, Chuon O. is taking out her loan to use as capital to buy more vegetables for sale. With the rest of the funds, she will buy a boat for assisting her jobless son.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables for sale and to buy a boat for assisting her jobless son

loans.name: Channat

texts.en:
Mrs. Channat B. is a widow. She has two sons, one has full-time employment and another one is in school. She lives about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Mrs. Channat B. runs a grocery store at home. She buys grocery items from Phnom Penh market and resells to her village. She asked for a Kiva loan once, and she now hopes to continue her business. So she is asking for another loan of $1,000 to purchase grocery items for her inventory.

loans.use: to purchase grocery items for her inventory

loans.name: Myadagsuren

texts.en: Myadagsuren, 44, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They live in their own house on a small plot of land that they own. Her husband helps her with the business and her two daughters attend a local school. Myadagsuren began selling foodstuffs out of a rented stall in 2006. Now her business has become more stable and she operates four stalls. She attracts her customers by offering a cheaper price and a better quality service than her competitors. She is going to get an additional stall, as it helps her to make more profit. She is a hardworking and honest person who says, " I want to have my own stalls or a store so that I can save money on rent. My daughters are going to attend a college in a few years and I have to pay their tuition fees." She is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 MNT to purchase  more grocery products for her business.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery products

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria B., 54, exerts her best efforts as she manages two micro-businesses at the same time. Her poor educational background of not being able to reach college doesn’t factor much into her current position, considering the amount of entrepreneurial training and Biblical encouragement she receives from CCT*. Victoria is married to Leonardo, part of the maintenance personnel. They have two children; one is in college while the other is in elementary school. They presently reside at Sta. Cruz 1, Dasmariñas, Cavite. 

Running a "carinderia" (food stall) is Victoria’s daily task. Often, she prepares the menu and cooks the meals. She also does the serving, as she has no employees at present. She is quite knowledgeable about her customers’ preferences, based on her seven years of experience in this kind of business. Also, she sells "Yakult" (is a Japanese probiotic milk-like product made by fermenting a mixture of skimmed milk with a special strain of the bacterium Lactobacillus casei Shirota) drinks to her neighbors. Altogether, she is able to earn PHP 8,000 as a net income monthly.

She exerts another effort to level up her business in terms of applying for a loan amounting to PHP 11,000. This will greatly help her grow her business. It will enable her to purchase quality ingredients and expand the meals she cooks for her customers. Improvement of facilities and utensils will be paid attention to as well. Victoria acknowledges that the loan will impact the profitability of her business and will allow her to save up for future use.

It is Victoria’s desire to be successful and for her family to have a better standard of living. That is why no matter how hard the challenges are she strives to give her best efforts to attain the best she can be.  As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she has received.

*All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy ingredients to prepare additional meals.

loans.name: 18-4-78 Quảng Hưng Group

texts.en:
Tương N. Thị (106) is a 57-year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hoá. Tương is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 78 Quảng Hưng (18.4.78 Quảng Hưng).

Tương is widowed and has four adult children. To make a living, Tương raises ducks for sale. Tương has been engaged in this business for over 15 years and earns approximately 700,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2011, Tương joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation.  Tương is requesting her first loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She is requesting a loan of 4,248,000 VND, which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. Tương plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About the other borrowers in the group:
1. P. Thị Chăm (107) is a 39-year-old woman who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her business of making and selling food.

2. T. Thị Hằng (108) is a 29-year-old woman who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her business of raising livestock.

3.

loans.use: to purchase breeding livestock

loans.name: Gombo

texts.en:
Gombo is 23 years old and lives with his wife and his newborn daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They live in a 'ger', a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in someone's backyard. His wife helps him with the business besides taking care of their infant daughter. 

Gombo began selling children's clothing out of a rented stall in 2010. He brings the goods from China and sells them at the market. His business has become more stable and he has many regular customers. As a father of an infant child, he always tries to bring in good quality clothes. His current working capital is 1,500,000 MNT and he wants to increase it by expanding his business. 

Gombo is a hard-working and initiative person who says, "We currently live in someone's backyard and we are planning to buy a property by saving some money." He is requesting a loan of 1,500,000 MNT to purchase more clothing from China for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing from China.

loans.name: Adelita

texts.en:
Adelita is 35 years old and is a married woman. She has two children aged 8 and 3. Her husband works as a farmer and driver.

Adelita is a farmer working in San Francisco, Agusan Del Sur. She has been growing rice for seven years. Adelita sells her harvest to the market. Aside from farming, Adelita also owns and manages a sari-sari (variety) store. She wishes for her farm and store to grow.

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. In the future, Adelita hopes for her children to finish school and have bright futures.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Orgil

texts.en:
Orgil, 33, is married and lives with her husband and her parents in Dornod province, Mongolia. They live in a house on a small plot of land that they have owned since 2002. Her husband works as an assistant for a supermarket and earns 108,000 MNT monthly. 

Orgil began her own business by selling foodstuffs in 1999. She rents a stall at a local food market and her current working capital exceeds 1,600,000 MNT. She wants to expand her business and increase her revenue. She is planning to operate an additional stall that sells consumer goods. She is requesting a loan of 2,500,000 MNT to purchase foodstuffs and consumer goods from Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs and consumer goods.

loans.name: Nak

texts.en:
Mr. Nak C. (pictured above) is 28 years old, and his wife Mrs. Sreylim Khut is 23 years old. They have been married since 2007 and have one young son. They live in a suburb of Phnom Penh, about 15 kilometers away from the city. 

Nak is a construction worker, while his wife is a garment factory worker. He is asking for his first loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike for commuting

loans.name: Anilyn

texts.en:
49-year-old Anilyn is a married woman with four children. Her oldest child is 24 years old and the youngest is 20.

Anilyn is a farmer. She has been growing rice for 25 years. Anilyn earns through selling her harvest. She works hard to keep her farm productive.

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies. In the future, Anilyn hopes to see all her children succeed.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Ra

texts.en:
Mr. Ra M. (pictured here) and his wife, Mrs. Sreypov Bun, have been married since 2000 and have one son and two daughters. They live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Mr. Ra M. asked for Kiva loan once, he now is asking for another loan of $300 to repair the house where he lives.

loans.use: to repair the house where he lives

loans.name: Mendee

texts.en:
Mendee, 44,  is married and lives with his wife and son in Govi-Altai province, Mongolia. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, on a small plot of land that they own. His wife helps him with the business and his son attends a local secondary school.

 Mendee began retail trading of clothes in 2009. He started his business with a working capital of 600,000 MNT and his current working capital exceeds 3,000,000 MNT. His business is family-based as his wife helps him with the sales. They want to expand their business and increase their revenue. 

Mendee is a hard-working and honest person. He is requesting a loan of 2,500,000 MNT to purchase more clothes from China for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes from China.

loans.name: Syneath

texts.en:
Mrs. Syneath S. (in the photo) is 29 years old and her husband, Mr. Sokha Ok, is 31 years old. They have been married since 2007 and have one young son. The family lives along National Road Number Six about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Syneath and her husband are garment factory workers. She wants to raise a cow when they are not at work, so she will be able to earn extra income from selling the cow when it grows big enough. So, Syneath is requesting her first loan of $500 to buy a cow.

loans.use: to purchase a cow to raise

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is a 48-year-old married woman with three children. Her children's ages are 13, 12 and 10.

Evelyn is engaged in farming. She helps her husband, who is a farmer, plant and harvest rice crops. Evelyn's husband mainly manages the farm. She also makes rice cakes and other delicacies that she sells around their neighborhood. Evelyn does her best to help provide for the family.

Evelyn's loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. In the future, she hopes for her familiy's living conditions to improve.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
A married parent of four children, Marcelina works hard to support her family.

She has a water refilling business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from pig fattening.  Marcelina is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to purchase refill bottles for her water refilling business.

Marcelina has been sustaining her business activities through her past 23 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to support her grandchildren in school.

loans.use: to purchase bottles for her water refilling business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Channa

texts.en:
Mrs. Channa H. (pictured above) and her husband, Mr. Sol Put, live in a village across Mekong River about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 2000 and have three children, two sons and one daughter.

Channa used to be a weaver, but she stopped the weaving business. She also runs a new business where she sells vegetables. Her husband is a farmer and fisherman. She is asking for a loan of $600 to repair the house where she lives.

loans.use: to repair the house where she lives

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is 52 years old and is a married woman. She has two children aged 24 and 4.

Gloria is a farmer. She tills a plot of land located in San Francisco, Agusan Del Sur. Her husband is also a farmer. She said that they both work hard to improve their harvest and earnings. Gloria also does her best to be the best mother to her children.

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Munhtulga

texts.en:
Munhtulga is 22 years old and lives with his parents in Hovd province, Mongolia. He began operating a cell phone repair service in 2009 and he supports his parents with his profits. He is a hard-working and polite person. He wants to expand his business and increase his business revenue. 

Munhtulga says, "I am planning to buy a car and start a taxi service so that I can increase my income." He is requesting a loan of 600,000 MNT as he needs extra money in addition to his savings to buy a car and operate a taxi service business.

loans.use: To buy a car and start a taxi service.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine B., 32, believes a bright future ahead begins with a right start.  She is married to Noel, a welder, and blessed with three children.  One is in elementary education and the other two are not yet of school age.  Josephine makes sure that she helps her husband earn for the daily needs of their family and prepare for the bright future also of their children. Together, they live in Burol 1, Dasmariñas, Cavite.

Josephine operates her own ready-to-wear business selling such as apparel, brassieres, accessories and even footwear items.  She has been in this business a year now and she has been able to establish relationship among her customers.  In fact, she already knows the designs, styles and preferred choices of her patrons.  She serves her neighbors and the local community.  Monthly, she earns an estimated net income of around Php 8,000.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a Php 14,000 loan.  She plans to use this amount to pay for the purchase of additional merchandise to restock her inventory.  Josephine believes an increase in her earnings will result from the proper use of this loan.

Right now, she prays for good health and a happy family life.  It's her fervent prayer that all her children will be able to finish their college education, to become strong and God-fearing individuals.  As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she has received.

*All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional apparel and accessories for resale.

loans.name: Liezel

texts.en:
Liezel is a 31-year-old married woman who lives in San Francisco, Agusan Del Sur, with her family. She has 4 children, the oldest of whom is 12 years old.

Liezel is in the business of raising hogs. She has a small backyard piggery that she hopes to expand soon. She plans to use her loan to purchase piglets and feeds. 

In the future, Liezel hopes for her business to grow. She also hopes for her children to finish school and have bright futures.

loans.use: to purchase piglets and feeds

loans.name: Nergui

texts.en: Nergui is a 41 year-old widow, and lives with her three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live together in ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.  Her two sons are helping her business and her daughter attends a university. Nergui operates a construction material business and also produces metal nails in a rented stall at the largest market in her town. There are few competing businesses at this market, and her business has seen steady growth. Through the years, Nergui has gained much experience and grown her business. She hopes to save some money to build her own house and to be able to provide for her children’s education. She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to increase her working profit by buying some metals to produce metal nails.

loans.use: to purchase some metals to produce metal nails.

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian is a 44 year-old  married woman with 2 children, aged 10 and 15. Lilian and her husband are both farmers. They till their land for planting rice crops. Lilian's husband mainly manages the farm and she also helps in keeping it productive. She also sells RTW clothes to the people in her community.

Lilian's loan will be used to purchase farm inputs, like fertilizers and seeds. Lilian hopes to earn more and be able to provide for her children's education.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs like fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Lyn

texts.en:
Lyn is a 43-year-old married woman with four children. Her oldest child is 21 and the youngest is 3.

Lyn is engaged in farming. She has been growing rice for seven years. Lyn earns through selling her harvest to the market. Lyn also opened a sari-sari (variety) store to add to the family's income. She sells items like canned goods and detergent.

Lyn's loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies. She hopes to be able to sustain her children's education.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda works hard to support her family. Erlinda is married and has a dried fish vending business in the Philippines.

Erlinda requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to buy dried fish to sell.

Erlinda has been in this business for eight years now and also earns additional income from pig fattening.

In the future, Erlinda would like to renovate their house.

loans.use: to purchase dried fish to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Normalita's Group

texts.en:
Normalita O. is from the village of Holy Friday, Mallig, Isabela. She is 58 years old. Normalita is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Normalita O.'s Group".

Normalita is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Normalita owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for breeding. Normalita has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Normalita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Normalita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Normalita is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 12th loan taken out by Normalita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

loans.name: Khoem

texts.en:
Khoem S. is a 60-year-old widowed villager who lives in Kompong Cham province. She is the mother of one child who earns money by working in a garment factory as a sewing worker. Her husband died of senility years ago. 

Khoem S. is a local farmer who has been planting a variety of crops for years. Recently, she has had a plan to raise many small fishes, but she has a problem with financial factor. In order to achieve her plan, Khoem S. has requested a loan to dig a pond where small fish grow, and she will also catch them to sell when the fish are mature. Note: Khoem S. and her grandson are in the photo.

loans.use: to dig a pond for raising small fish

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia R. is from the village of Talisay. She is 59 years old, is married, and has four children: three of them are adults and the youngest is school-aged.

Delia owns and operates a business providing electronic services such as appliance repair and video karaoke assembly to the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Delia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from PMPC.

Delia is requesting a new loan of 14,500 PHP which will be used as tuition fee payment for her son. This will be her 11th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business and also to support the education of her youngest child.

loans.use: to use as tuition fee payment for her son.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa is 47 years old and married with four children. Elsa works very hard to provide for them.

Elsa runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stock to sell.

Elsa has been in this business for seven years and sells a variety of items such as soft drinks, curls, shampoo, candy and other miscellaneous items. 

In the future, Elsa would like to repair her house.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more goods for her general store.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria tiene 54 años de edad y es casado con hijos mayores. Vive en casa propia con su esposo en el distrito de La Matanza en la provincia de Morropon, unas cuatro horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo, la capital de la región de Lambayeque. 

Desde hace dos años, María cuenta con una pequeña bodega instalada en su domicilio. Allí ofrecen en venta a los vecinos y clientes de la zona diversos productos de consumo diario, entre productos de primera necesidad y abarrotes. María es muy conocida en la zona y tiene una clientela establecida. Con este negocio, ella puede solventar sus gastos personales y familiares.

Como ya ha comenzado la temporada escolar en Perú, sus clientes están comprando suministros para sus hijos. María quiere responder a la demanda de sus clientes con la compra de más útiles escolares. Por ello, ha creído conveniente solicitar un préstamo de 2000 nuevos soles a Edpyme Alternativa. María cuenta con buenas referencias personales y laborales. Ella es un cliente recurrente de Edpyme Alternativa y ha cumplido con sus otras obligaciones de manera puntual. Agradece a los prestamistas de Kiva por su ayuda en aumentar su negocio.
texts.en:
Maria is a 54-year-old married mother with grown children. She lives in her own home with her husband in the La Matanza district of the Morropon province, located some four hours away from the city of Chiclayo, the capital of the Lambayeque region.

For two years, Maria has been running a small general store from home. There, she sells daily consumption products, such as basic need items and other goods. Maria is well-known in the area and has a solid client-base. With his business, she is able to cover both her personal and family expenses.

Since the school season has already started in Peru, her customers are currently purchasing school supplies for their children. Maria wants to meet this demand by purchasing more school supplies. For this reason, she sees the need to request a 2,000.00 PEN loan from Edpyme Alternativa. Maria has good personal and work references. She is a returning client of Edpyme Alternativa's and has fulfilled her prior commitments punctually. She is grateful to the Kiva lenders for their support in helping her business grow.

loans.use: to purchase school supplies to sell in her general store

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 34 years old and married with four children.

Erlinda works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stock to sell.

Erlinda has borrowed and paid three loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for eight years and also earns an income from food vending.

Erlinda aspires to send her children to school.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for his children's educational expenses

loans.name: Isedrelita

texts.en:
Isedrelita works hard to support her family. Isedrelita is single and has an abaca weaving business in the Philippines.

Isedrelita requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy materials for abaca weaving.

Isedrelita has been in this business for seven years.

In the future, Isedrelita would like to educate her children and improve the business.

loans.use: to buy materials for abaca weaving

loans.name: Melania

texts.es: Melania tiene 48 años D. edad, es casada y tiene dos hijos a su cargo. Vive en casa propia en una comunidad urbana en el distrito D. La Matanza, ubicado en el norte D. Perú. DesD. hace dos años, Melania se dedica al comercio D. útiles escolares. Su negocio está instalado en su domicilio. Melania es muy conocida en la zona y tiene una clientela establecida. Como ya ha comenzado la temporada escolar en Perú, la demanda para suministros escolares ha aumentado. Melania quiere responder a esta demanda y por ello, ha creído conveniente solicitar un préstamo D. 1000 nuevos soles a Edpyme Alternativa para la compra D. más mercadería. Melania cuenta con buenas referencias personales y laborales D. su comunidad. Es muy trabajadora y siempre vela por el bienestar y desarrollo D. su familia. Agradece a los prestamistas D. Kiva por su ayuda en aumentar su negocio.
texts.en: Melania is a 48-year-old married mother with two children under her care. She lives in her own home in an urban community of the La Matanza district, located in northern Peru. For two years, Melania has been in the school supply business. Her business is located in her home. Melania is well-known in the area and has a solid client-base. Since the school season has already begun in Peru, demand for her school supplies has increased. Melania would like to respond to this demand, which is why she thinks that it is opportune to request a 1,000.00 PEN loan from Edpyme Alternativa, so that she can purchase more merchandise. She is very hardworking and is always attentive to her family's development and well-being. She gives thanks to the Kiva lenders for their support in helping her business grow.

loans.use: Increase school supplies

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena is 49 years old and is a married woman with nine children. Her oldest child is 30 years old and the youngest is 14. 

Magdalena is a farmer working in San Francisco, Agusan Del Sur. She has been growing rice for 30 years. She earns about 2000 PHP per month from this farming. Magdalena works hard to improve her business and earnings.

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. She hopes for her business to grow.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Maria Betty

texts.es: Maria tiene 24 años de edad y es soltera. Vive en casa con sus padres en la parte rural del distrito de Olmos en el norte de Perú. Actualmente, no cuenta con servicios básicos de agua y luz. Desde hace dos años, se dedica a la compra y venta de pollo. Ella compra los animales de sus vecinos que los crían para luego venderlos al público general en el mercado local. Con sus ingresos, ella puede solventar sus gastos personales y apoyar a sus padres con sus gastos familiares. Desea aumentar su mercadería con la compra de más animales para vender. Por ello, ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un préstamo de 500 nuevos soles. María agradece a los prestamistas de Kiva por su apoyo en crecer su negocio.
texts.en: Maria is 24 years old and single. She lives in her parents' home in a rural area of the Olmos district in northern Peru. She currently does not have basic services like electricity  and running water. For two years, she has been buying and selling chickens for a living. She buys the animals from her neighbors, who raise and subsequently sell the chickens to the general public at the local market. With the proceeds, she is able to cover her personal expenses and help her parents with the family expenses. She would like to increase her stock by purchasing more animals to sell. For this reason, she thinks that it is opportune to request a  500.00 PEN loan from Edpyme Alternativa. Maria gives thanks to the Kiva lenders for their support in helping her business grow.

loans.use: Purchase more animals to sell

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita L., 58, runs her own variety store together with her husband Wyler.  They have been blessed with two children who are settled and have established their own families.  Every day, Nenita sees to it that she earns well for their daily needs.  They presently live in Sta. Maria, Dasmariñas, Cavite.

Nenita runs a variety store. In the Philippines, the sari-sari store (variety store) allows members of the community easy access to basic commodities at low costs. It is a place to buy candies, canned goods, sachets of shampoo;  cooking oil, salt and sugar are often repackaged into Php5-Php10 per pack.  She has been in this kind of business for years now.  Monthly, she earns an estimated net income of around Php 8,000.

To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting a Php 21,000 loan.  She plans to use this amount to pay for the purchase of additional grocery items to restock her inventory.  Nenita believes an increase on her earnings will result from the proper use of this loan.

Nenita desires her family to stay strong, to have harmonious relationship always, and remain healthy physically.  As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

*All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional grocery items for her store.

loans.name: Maria Siria

texts.es: María tiene 34 años de edad, es separada y tiene 2 hijos menores de edad escolar. Vive en casa propia en la zona rural del distrito de Morrope en el norte de Perú. Su comunidad es pequeña con un aproximado de 200 familias. Recientemente cuenta con servicios de luz y agua. Desde hace 2 años, Maria se dedica a la venta de ropa y cerveza. Su negocio está situado en su domicilio. Ella inició esta actividad para generar ingresos después de la separación de su esposo. María conoce a la perfección el rubro y cuentan con una clientela ya establecida en la zona. Desea usar su crédito para invertir en la compra de ropa escolar tanto uniformes como ropa deportiva para colegiales. Ahora que la temporada escolar ha comenzado en Perú, ella quiere poder responder a la demanda de sus clientes para estos productos. Por ello, ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un préstamo de 1000 nuevos soles. María goza de muy buenas referencias personales y laborales. Es muy trabajadora y responsable. Su mayor anhelo de siempre es darles un mejor nivel de vida a sus dos hijos.
texts.en:
María is 34 years old, separated from her spouse, and has two young children who are in school. She lives in her own home in the rural section of the District of Morrope in northern Peru. This small community has approximately 200 families. María recently received services such as electricity and water.

For the past two years, María has been selling clothing and beer. Her business is located in her home. She started this business to generate income after the separation from her husband. María is a perfectionist in her work and has an established customer base in the area.

She wants to use her loan to invest in the purchase of school clothing, ranging from uniforms to high school sportswear. Now that the school year has started in Peru, she wants to respond to the demands of her customers for these products. For this reason, she is requesting a loan from Edpyme Alternativa in the amount of 1000 PEN.

María has earned good personal and work-related references. She is hardworking and responsible. Her greatest wish is to always provide her two children with a better quality of life.

loans.use: To purchase school clothes to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay the school expenses of his young children.

loans.name: Mercedita

texts.en:
Mercedita is a married woman from San Francisco, Agusan Del Sur. She is 58 years old and has no children.

Mercedita has been in the business of raising hogs for 25 years. She plans to use her loan to purchase piglets and feed. Her husband is a farmer and she also helps in keeping their rice farm free of weeds and pests.

In the future, Mercedita would like for her piggery to grow.

loans.use: to purchase piglets and feed

loans.name: Agripina

texts.en:
Agripina is married with seven children. Four of the children are in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Agripina is 49 years old. 

Agripina has a charcoal vending business in the Philippines. Agripina requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stock of charcoal to sell.

Agripina has been in this business for three years.  In the future, Agripina would like to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy more stock of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Omidin

texts.en:
Omidin D. is 39 years old, married, and has three daughters. He worked as a driver in his local area and was engaged in breeding cattle, but his earnings didn’t cover his family’s expenses. For this reason, he started selling vegetables at the local market in 2002. With the revenues, he was able to buy a car for transportation of the goods. 

Five months ago, Omidin decided to change his direction to selling footwear with the starting capital 30.000 KGS and has rented a small shop. Today he has goods to the amount of 50.000 KGS and earns about 12.000 KGS in a month. Omidin has applied for a loan of 90.000 KGS to broaden the assortment of footwear in his shop. It will allow him to raise his sales and further develop his business. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to broaden an assortment of shoe goods for sale

loans.name: Rocelyn

texts.en:
Rocelyn is 39 years old and married with three children.

She earns a living by having a pig fattening business in the Philippines. Rocelyn is borrowing PHP 14,000 through NWTF to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Rocelyn has been in this business for 15 years and earns additional income from a general store.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream to do some house improvements.

loans.use: to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Isidora

texts.es: Isidora tiene 47 años D. edad, es casada y tiene 2 hijos. Vive en casa propia, la cual está ubicada en la parte rural del distrito D. Tucume en el norte D. Perú. DesD. hace ocho años, se dedica a la crianza y venta D. animales. Realiza esta actividad en un terreno situado cerca a su domicilio. Aprendió esta actividad D. su padre, es decir conoce a la perfección el rubro. Cuenta con una clientela ya establecida en la zona. Adicionalmente, se dedica a la compra y venta D. sábanas, edredones y colchas lo que  le genera ingresos  adicionales. Con estas actividades, ella pueD. apoyar a su esposo, quien trabaja como mototaxista, con los gastos familiares. Ha solicitado un préstamo D. 2000 nuevos soles para la compra D. más animales, alimento balanceado para sus animales y también para la compra D. sabanas, edredones y colchas. Espera aumentar sus ventas para generar más ingresos lo que ayudará mejorar la calidad D. vida D. su familia.
texts.en:
Isidora is 47 years old, married, and has two children. She lives in her own home in the rural section of the District of Tucume in northern Peru. Isidora has been raising and selling animals for eight years. Her business is conducted on a plot of land located near her home. She learned this traD. from her father who is known for being a perfectionist. Isidora has an established customer base in the area. In addition, she buys and sells bed sheets, quilts, and bedspreads to generate extra income. These activities enable her to help her husband, who works as a motorcycle taxi driver, with the family expenses.

Isidora is requesting a loan of 2000 PEN to buy more animals, balanced feed, as well as bed sheets, quilts, and bedspreads. She hopes to increase her sales so that she can generate more income to help improve her family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To purchase more animals, balanced feed, and bedding to sell.

loans.name: Presnida

texts.en:
Presnida is a 49-year-old married woman who lives in San Francisco, Agusan Del Sur, with her family. She has a 26-year-old child.

Presnida is engaged in farming. She cultivates her land for planting rice crops. Presnida sells her harvest to the market.  She also sells fruits and vegetables.

This loan will be used to purchase farm inputs, such as fertilizers and seeds. In the future, Presnida hopes for her family's living conditions to improve.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs, such as fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Olga Azucena

texts.es: Olga tiene 31 años de edad, es madre soltera con dos hijos menores de 06 y 03 años. Vive en casa de su madre en el distrito de José Leonardo Ortiz en la ciudad de Chiclayo, la capital de la región de Lambayeque. Desde hace más de dos años, se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza como maquillaje y perfumes por catalogo. Su negocio está ubicado en su domicilio. Es muy conocida en la zona y cuenta con una clientela ya establecida. Olga ha solicitado un crédito para ayudar con los gastos escolares de su hijo menor. Este préstamo permitirá que Olga trabaje tranquilo sin tener que recurrir a prestamistas informales que le cobrarían tasas altísimas, lo cual perjudica su liquidez diaria y retrasa su crecimiento tanto comercial como familiar. Olga cuenta con buenas referencias personales y laborales. Es muy trabajadora y responsable. Su mayor anhelo es ofrecer una mejor calidad de vida a sus dos hijos.
texts.en:
Olga is 31 years old and a single mother of two young children, ages 6 and 3. She lives at home with her mother in the District of José Leonardo Ortiz in the city of Chiclayo, the capital of Lambayeque region. For more than two years, Olga has been selling beauty products such as make-up and perfumes through a catalog. Her business is located in her home. She is well-known in her area and has an established customer base.

Olga is requesting a loan to help pay for the school expenses of her young son. This loan will allow her to work peacefully without having to resort to informal lenders who charge very high interest rates that would impact her daily liquidity and slow the growth of both her business and her family.

Olga has good personal and work-related references. She is hardworking and responsible. Her greatest wish is to provide her two children a better quality of life.

loans.use: To pay for her son's school expenses.

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es: Mercedes tiene 38 años de edad, es madre soltera y tiene con 2 hijos. Vive en casa propia con sus hijos la parte rural del distrito de Tambogrande, una zona agrícola situada en la región de Piura, a más de cuatro horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo, capital de la región de Lambayeque. Se dedica a la venta de frutas y jugos todos los días en su propio domicilio. Tiene más de 3 años de experiencia en este negocio. Es muy conocida en la zona y cuenta con clientela ya establecida en la zona. Sus ventas diarias son muy buenas pues su negocio está ubicado frente al paradero de carros y motos en el caserío. Desea invertir su crédito en la compra de más frutas para tener en stock y también para la compra de mesas y sillas para sus clientes. Mercedes es muy trabajadora y responsable. Las personas que le conocen le tienen mucha estima y cariño. Su mayor anhelo es seguir creciendo su negocio para poder ofrecerles una mejor calidad de vida a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Mercedes is 38 years old and a single mother of two children. She lives in her own home with her children in the rural section of the District of Tambogrande, an agricultural area situated in Piura Province, which is more than four hours away from the city of Chiclayo, the capital of Lambayeque region.

Mercedes sells fruits and juices from her home. She has more than three years of experience with this business. Mercedes is well-known in the area and has an established customer base. Her daily sales are good since her business is located in front of a taxi stand that is frequented by many cars and motorcycles from the village.

Mercedes wants to invest her loan in the purchase of more fruits to keep in stock. She will also buy tables and chairs for her customers. Mercedes is hardworking and responsible. The people who know her have great respect and affection for her. Her greatest wish is to continue growing her business so that she can offer a better quality of life for her children.

loans.use: To purchase fruit, tables, and chairs.

loans.name: Un

texts.en: Un S., 30, is a single woman who currently lives with her old mother in Kompong Chhnang province. She is the oldest of the three siblings. Un S.  could earn a living by growing rice and vegetable crops to sell for a profit. To help meet the needs of the family, her second sister works sewing clothes for industry. Un S. would like to request a loan to add to her personal savings to buy a plot of farmland near her house, which is a good location for farming. She will use this farmland to enlarge her crop-planting business. The loan will provide her with an additional new asset.

loans.use: to buy a plot of farmland in order to enlarge her crop-planting business

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie is 40 years old and is a married woman with 4 children. Her oldest child is 16 years old and the youngest is only 1 year old. Rosalie's husband works as a farmer.

Rosalie has been in the business of raising hogs for 20 years. She plans to use her loan to purchase pigs and feeds. Rosalie also helps her husband grow rice at their farm.

In the future, Rosalie hopes to see her children finish school and have bright futures.

loans.use: to purchase pigs and feeds

loans.name: Utuagiagi

texts.en:
Utuagiagi T. is starting a new business venture, which is raising cattle for sale. Utuagiagi is requesting a loan for 2,500 WST to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future.  She plans to use the profits from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to improve and expand her business.

Utuagiagi joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral. This is Utuagiagi's fourth loan with SPBD.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en: Rosalinda U. is married and has six children ranging in age from 5 to 24.  Rosalinda is engaged in farming and hog-raising. She helps her husband till their farm. They grow rice and then sell their harvest to the market. Rosalinda also manages their small backyard piggery. Rosalinda is requesting a loan for 4,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase fertilizers and pig feeds. She hopes to have a stable business that would sustain their family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and pig feeds

loans.name: Epenesa

texts.en:
Epenesa owns & operates a business venture selling dairy products in the local community.  She has two years of experience in this business.  Epenesa needs a loan of WST 1400 to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Epenesa joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Epenesa's 2nd loan with SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients needed to make products for sale.

loans.name: Maria Enina

texts.en:
Maria Enina owns & operates a business venture which is selling food products in the local community.  She has 2 years of experience in this business. Maria needs a loan of WST $1500 to purchase additional food products to sell.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Maria joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral.  This is Maria's 2nd loan with SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase additional food products to sell

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
For Wilma B., the more blessings one receives, the more that person is enabled to give. Wilma, 47, focuses on making her shop grow but more than that, she sees to it that she does help other people. Wilma is a life partner to Nicomedes, an overseas Filipino worker (OFW), and mother to two children. One studies in high school, while the other is in elementary.  They presently live in Malaria, Caloocan City.

Wilma’s business is two-pronged. First, she is into direct sales. She sells items like clothes and shoes which go along with the taste of the customers. Also, she has a computer shop which she manages. It is located in the extension of their house and profits remarkably. Every month, Wilma earns an estimated net income of around Php 13,000.

To help her continue operation of her businesses, she is requesting a Php 20,000 loan. She intends to use this money to purchase two sets of computers, so that the shop can accommodate more clients.  Also, with part of this loan, she will purchase some cosmetics ordered in advance by her customers.

The rainy season hampers Wilma’s business. Nevertheless, she refuses to be hindered by business challenges from helping others, especially youth. Even as she meets the daily needs of her family, she desires to help others to meet their needs, too. For her, this is the way to become a successful business woman.  As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

*All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional two computer units and cosmetics ordered in advance by customers.

loans.name: Choem

texts.en: Choem M. is a 57-year-old village woman who has had a job as a rice farmer since she was single. She always uses her own farmland to grow rice crops at least two times per year. To help meet the family's daily expense needs, her husband works drivinga  motortaxi in and around his community, Kompong Chhnang province. They are blessed with three children; two are students in the local school while one is employed as a sewing worker and has a formal salary. Choem M. will take her loan to pay for harvesting costs as she hired a few domestic laborers to assist her this time.

loans.use: to pay for harvesting costs as she hired a few domestic laborers to assist her

loans.name: Taliloa

texts.en:
Taliloa owns & operates a business venture which is raising cattle for sale.  She has two years of experience in this business.  Taliloa needs a loan of WST 1000 to purchase baby cows to raise & sell in the future.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Taliloa joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Taliloa's 2nd loan with SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future.

loans.name: Otila

texts.en:
Otila owns & operates a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale. She has 4 years of experience in this business. Otila  needs a loan of WST $2450 to purchase weed killers such as Gramoxome. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 400 tala or US $167 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Otila joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral.  This is Otila's 5th loan with SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase weed killers such as Gramoxome for her farm

loans.name: Voeur

texts.en:
Voeur P. is 25 years of age and is a resident of Siem Reap province. To pursue a daily income, she works in the one local restaurant as an assistant cook because she is good at cooking delicious meals. She earns an income on average of $3 USD a day for meeting the family expenses. 

The other financial earner is her husband who is a motortaxi driver, making around $4 per day, and he shares responsibilities with Voeur P.. The couple doesn’t have kids yet. Presently, Voeur P. says she has a problem with traveling because she doesn’t have her own vehicle. She really wants to buy a new motorbike, but she doesn’t have enough cash to buy one. To solve this issue, Voeur P. is requesting a loan to purchase a new motorcycle for riding to her job location.

loans.use: to purchase a new motorcycle for riding to her job location

loans.name: Chhuon

texts.en: Chhuon S., 37, makes a living by selling recycled goods and growing rice on farmland that she owns in the province of Kompong Cham. She sells her used goods to a wholesaler who sells them in bulk to other countries. These recycled items include wires, cans, bottles and plastic goods. Her husband works in construction and earns about $2 a day. Chhuon S. has three children, all of whom are in school. She is applying for this loan to buy a cow.

loans.use: To buy a cow.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is from the village of P-2 Upper Centro, Tudela, Misamis Occidental 7209. She is 51 years old, married and has three children. To make a living, Jocelyn runs a business venture selling varieties of dried fish. 

Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities. Jocelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional dried fish to sell.

Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP with which she will purchase additional varieties of dried fish to sell. This will be the sevententh loan taken out by Jocelyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase various varieties of dried fish to sell.

location.town: P-2 Upper Centro, Tudela Misamis Occidental

loans.name: Range Group

texts.en:
Martina R., who is in her late thirties, is married with four children.  She sells fabrics from door to door.  She has been in this business for three years and works from 9.00am to 6.00pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Martina's 2nd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loan to increase her fabrics stock and has paid back successfully.  She hopes for a loan to open a shop where she will sell her fabrics and start selling juice and water.  Her dream is to one day buy a small car so that she will be mobile and deliver her fabrics to more customers.

Martina will share this loan with her loan group "Range" which has a total of 16 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Martina is behind second from right, back row.

loans.use: To open a shop for fabrics and sell soda and juice as well.

loans.name: Jitahidi Msakuzi Group

texts.en:
Magret B., who is in her  mid-twenties, is married with three children (two are twins).  She has been running a small cafe business for four years. She works from 6:00am to 10:00pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Magret's twelfth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to sell fruits and vegetables and also bought a plot of land.  She has repaid her loans successfully.  She hopes for a loan to increase her cafe's items (food and drinks).  Her dream is to one day have a big restaurant and also send her children to good schools.

Magret will share this loan with her loan group "Jitahidi Msakuzi", which has a total of 16 members.  The members will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Magret is behind, last row 3rd from right.

loans.use: To increase her small cafe items.

loans.name: Florentina's Group

texts.en:
Florentina S. is from the village of San Jose. She is 51 years old. Florentina is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Florentina S. Group".

Florentina is married and has three children. To make a living, Florentina owns & operates a business venture in the services sector providing waste management services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from operating tricycle transport waste-management services. Florentina has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Florentina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florentina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to pay for registration, franchise and licenses. Florentina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to repair existing vehicle for better service. This will be the 9th loan taken out by Florentina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair existing vehicle for better service.

loans.name: Ammabille

texts.en:
Ammabille F. lives in the village of San Simon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 35 years old, married, has two school-aged children and makes a living by raising livestock, including pigs and goats. She has been in this business for more than five years and earns about 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Ammabille joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid seven previous loans from HSPFI and has applied for a new one to buy feed and medicines for her livestock. She plans to use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to continue expanding her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy feed and medicine for her livestock.

location.town: San Simon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Kibondo Group

texts.en:
Mwanahamis B., who is in her mid-forties, is married with three grown-up children. She has been running a food vendor business for two years.  She works from 6:00am to 9:00pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Mwanahamis's tenth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to go to Kilosa, which is about 320 kilometres from Dar es Salam, to take ladies' clothes, pants, and petticoats and sell them to the villagers. She also sold charcoal at her place, Kimara. She paid back her loans successfully.  She hopes for a loan to go to Kariakoo, which is about three kilometres from the city centre, to buy Arab-style traditional dresses (very long and large, say free-size) and sell them door-to-door.

Mwanahamis will share this loan with her loan group "Kibondo" which has a total of 18 members.  The members of the group will hold each accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Mwanahamis is in the back, fourth from right, just next to a lady in pink.

loans.use: To go to Kariakoo Market and buy long and large dresses.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria T. lives the village of Santo Niño, Manolo Fortich, Bukidnon. She is 38 years old, married, has three school-aged children and makes a living by running a sari-sari (or variety) store. She sells items such as canned goods, snacks, shampoo, soap, bread and beverages to people in her community. Gloria has been in this business for more than 11 years and earns about 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Gloria joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid six previous loans from HSPFI and is applying for a new one to buy more items to sell to her customers. She plans to use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Silvina

texts.en:
Silvina is a married woman with six children. She is 48 years old and has had a sari-sari (variety) store for two years.

Silvina sells items like sugar, canned goods, and coffee to the people in her community. She usually earns about 2000 PHP per month with her store. Silvina's husband is a farmer. She also helps him till their land for planting rice crops.

Silvina is requesting a loan of 6000 PHP to buy more items to sell, such as sugar and canned goods.

In the future, Silvina hopes to have a better house.

loans.use: to purchase items to resell such as sugar and canned goods.

loans.name: Prescilla's Group

texts.en:
Prescilla E. is from the village of San Pedro. She is 50 years old. Prescilla is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Prescila E.'s Group".

Prescilla is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Prescilla owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Prescilla has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Prescilla joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Prescilla has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Prescilla is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Prescilla from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering.

loans.name: Adela

texts.en:
Adela R. lives in the village of Taglimao, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 61 years old, widowed and has five grown children. She makes a living by running a  sari-sari (or variety) store where she sells canned goods, snacks, detergents, shampoo, soap, biscuits and beverages to people in her community. She has been in this business for more than 10 years and earns about 12,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Adela joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid five previous loans from HSPFI and is applying for a new one to buy more items to sell to her customers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by this loan to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is a partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell to her customers.

location.town: Taglimao, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en: Virginia O. is 48 years old, widowed, and has three children.  They live in Trinidad, Bohol. She earns a living through farming and food vending. She tills the land where she plants and harvests rice. She also cooks rice cakes and other delicacies, which she sells to the people in her community. Virginia is requesting a loan for 5,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase fertilizers and ingredients such as sugar and flour. She hopes to be able to sustain her children's education. She also wants to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and ingredients such as sugar and flour

loans.name: Tembo Mgwaza Group

texts.en:
Mary K., who is in her early thirties, is married with five children.  She has had a chicken business for 12 years. She works from 5:00am to 8:00pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Mary's fourth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to start the chicken business, sold fabrics and also bought a plot of land.  She has paid back her loans successfully.  She hopes for a new loan to buy chicken feed.  Her dream is to have a big space where she can have a good number of chickens.

Mary will share this loan with her loan group "Tembo Mgwaza", which has a total of 15 members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Mary is in front, 1st on the right, with a flowered dress.

loans.use: To buy chicken feed.

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie L. lives in the village of Balulang, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 43 years old, married, has two grown children and makes a living by running a sari-sari (or variety) store where she sells canned goods, snacks, beverages, shampoo, soap and biscuits to people in her community. She has been in this business for more 11 years and earns about 9,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Tessie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid four loans from HSPFI and is applying for a new one to  to buy more items to sell to her customers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by this loan to expand her business.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is a partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell to her customers.

location.town: Balulang, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Febe

texts.en:
Febe is 38 years old and married with one child in school.  Febe works very hard to provide for them.

Febe runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 28,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stock for the general store.

Febe has been in this business for one year and sells a variety of items such as coffee, bread, sugar etc. 

In the future, Febe would like to do some home improvements.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a 27 years old and single. She has a 3-year-old child.

Elizabeth sells fish to earn a living. She buys directly from fishermen and sells assorted fresh fish to the market. She also plants and harvests seaweed. Elizabeth plans to use her loan to purchase a fishing boat which will help her have more fish to sell.

In the future, Elizabeth hopes to have a stable business.

loans.use: to purchase a fishing boat.

loans.name: Ludina

texts.en:
Ludina E. is from the village of Balulang, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 45 years old. Ludina is married and has eight school-aged children. Ludina owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, junk food, shampoo, soap, biscuits & beverages in the local community. Ludina has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2009, Ludina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from HSPFI, which was for 14,000 PHP and was used to purchase additional inventory & as working capital.

Ludina is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to to purchase additional canned goods, junk food & beverages. This loan will be her fifth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, junk food, & beverages

In 2009, Filipina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Filipina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Filipina is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell such as canned goods and soft drinks. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Filipina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Erlina

texts.en:
Erlina is a married woman with four children. She is 35 years old and has had a sari-sari (variety) store for 8 years.

Erlina sells items like sugar, canned goods and soap to the people in her community. Erlina's husband is a fisherman. She helps him by selling all his catch to the market.

Erlina is requesting a loan of 13,000 PHP to to purchase fishing hooks, nets and items to resell such as canned goods.

In the future, she hopes to have all her children finish college.

loans.use: to purchase fishing hooks, nets and items to resell such as canned goods.

loans.name: Mukisa Development Group-Kampala

texts.en:
35-year-old M. Nelson is a firewood and coffee sales businessman who has been operating his  business for the past 8 years in Gayaza-Kampala. The amiable father of two says he began this business with the persuasion of close friends who had seen success in similar businesses. 

Before that, Nelson was involved in a glass sales trade. Nelson also has a pig husbandry business on the side. Weekly he says the firewood business brings in shillings 25,000 as profits. With this loan, he says he is going to purchase more firewood and coffee to resell.

loans.use: to purchase more firewood and coffee to resell

loans.name: Margie Lyn's Group

texts.en:
Margie Lyn D. S. is from the village of San Pascual, Diffun, Quirino. She is 38 years old. Margie Lyn is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Margie Lyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Margie Lyn owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Margie Lyn has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Margie Lyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Margie Lyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Margie Lyn is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Margie Lyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.
